article: When someone says, Well, I guess I ll have to go to face the music. It doesn t mean he is planning to go to a concert. It is _ less pleasant, like _ in by your boss to explain why you did this and did that, and why you did not do this _ that. Terrible music, indeed, but it has to _ . At some time or _ , every one of us has had to face the music , especially as children. We can all remember father s _ voice, I want to talk to you! and only _ we did not obey him. What an unpleasant business it _ ! The phrase to face the music is known _ every American, young and old. It is at least 100 years old. Where did the _ come from? The first _ comes from American novelist James Fennimore Cooper. He said, in 1851, _ the expression was first _ by actors while waiting in the _ to go on stage. After they got their clue to go on, they often said, It s time to go to face the music. And this is _ what they did face the orchestra which was just below the stage. An actor might be frightened or _ as he moved on to the stage in front of him. The audience might be friendly, or perhaps unfriendly, especially _ he forgot his lines. But he had to go out. If he did not, there would be no play. So, to face the music _ to mean: having to go _ something, no matter how unpleasant the _ might be, because you knew you had no choice
